Boglornch here, I just showed up to this thread but I lurked the last one a bit.

My opinion is literally just that I really like the art style started by Sugimori, but some of the SV ones have that weird 3d look that tells me they were rushed, and those ones all have really boring static looking poses. It's a personal thing I find sad after years of mostly more fun illustrations.

It isn't that the pose is similar. It's the quality of the linework, coloring and shading. It looks off and less pleasant. It's not a big deal or overall criticism of the games, I really had no idea this was something that would even be slightly controversial let alone a giant shitstorm.

The type of thing I'm talking about, drawing with the aid of 3d models, can even look very good. Some of the better art that I like could have even been done that way; the artist just did a good job of making the result look like a more raw drawing.

In all the discussion about Greninja so far there is one thing that I haven't seen mentioned.

Before these raids they run two special raids to give us a Pokemon to help us in the seven star. This pokemon never ends up being meta or ohko capable, at least not so far. But I do think it tells us something about the raid.

For example, before Charizard there was mimikyu and florges raids. This should have signaled to everyone that fairy was going to be viable and that Charizard would not have a steel attack

Similarly, before cinderrace, we got Gyarados and Gengar. Cinderrace did not end up having electro ball and ended up being more weak on the special side with how much it spammed bulk up.

The two pokemon being run before Greninja are.... Lucario and bronzing.
What does this tell us about Greninja?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53019001
I'm not the best at explaining, but here we go

First thing is you can't see anyone else while in Area 0. However, they can see the pokemon you spawn and can fight them.

Basic rules, are we fly to area zero, all eat the correct level 3 shiny sandwich, and then go to right area to hunt for shinies. In our case, we'd go to the 4th research station. A lot of Iron Valiants spawn there, and you can look for shiny flutter mane around Lab Zero at the bottom.

Just keep in mind that any pokemon that you spawn only stay in your field of vision and not everyones. So say I see a Flutter Mane that you spawn, and you move far enough away that it despawns for you. It would despawn for me as well.

If one of us finds a shiny, just make a post alerting the other person. Because two people can catch the same shiny, the person who spawned it, and one other person in the union circle. All the person who spawned it has to do is save and then reload their save after the shiny is caught and it will reappear for them.


tl;dr
1. Picnic at Aera Zero and eat for right shiny type
2. Go to area where your target spawns
3. Find shiny
4. Alert partner you found shiny
5. Save before they fight it.
6. They catch shiny
7. You restart your game
8. You catch the shiny too.
9. ???
10. PROFIT!!!

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53026056
What? It really wasn't there. I though I got that one from auctions but was probably lucky to get one from AFK Ace Tournament.

>>53026063
>Turn off auto save
>Clear all the existing auctions (you can enter and give up instead of spending money)
>Save in front of the Auction house
>Close the game.
>Move the switch time at least 2 hours forward
>Open the game and see if there are apriballs in the auctions if not close the game and open it again
And Yes APRIBALLS I got lucky and got 2 balls in one reset and one was a Love ball too.

posts.com:
>>53023759
I forget that's the way of things myself since it's such a huge turn off to me, but it's true that Western art is dominated by that stuff. Honestly doesn't make sense to me to reduce every single character to the same blob in a different wig. Where's the fun in removing all character specific scenarios and traits to do the same thing over and over?

Anyway I like how a lot of Arven art draws his shirt getting a bit taut over his chest, it would be cute to see him fussing about whether he needs to apply for new uniform in a bigger size. The academy has been looking after him all this time, so he doesn't want to trouble them, but it's kinda too tight sometimes. Maybe he should just bear with it and avoid moving in ways that strain the fabric, at least until next school term. Arven's face turns red, and his lips hold tightly together after a button pops off mid class. He could die right here, fizzle into nothing, please arceus don't let them all be looking at me. The noise was so damn loud there's no way nobody heard it. He turns his head slowly and starts to sit back upright, clinging to the wayward pen he'd dropped on the floor as though it explained everything. The silent pause in Raifort's lecture feels as though it's gone on for minutes already. As her words continue, he realises no one in front has turned back. He feels the chill of sweat down his nape, suddenly aware of how tense his whole body had been and unsure how to relax and sit normally again. His eyes scan around and spot the button on the floor not far from the teacher's desk. Could he collect it covertly on the way out? Drop his pen "by accident" again? Is it even worth sewing back on? His thoughts come to an abrupt halt at a thumping on his arm. He stiffly turns in horror.
"Nice tits," whispers the strange boy sat next to him, raising an approving thumbs up. Of course Florian saw. It takes all his power not to yell.

>Apparently people want them
Because nostalgiafags make up the majority of the fandom. They wouldn't put out so many remakes if this wasn't the case.
>If people wanted to play Digimon they wouldn't have bought Pokémon
Ironically current Digimon mogs the fuck out of current Pokemon.
>Who's forcing you to use old mons
You're missing the point. The reason Kantomons became popular is because they were they only ones you could get for years. The new mons fail to become popular is because people get stuck in their old ways and refuse to change what already works. By making it so you can only access the old mons after you beat the Pokemon league it gives the game a fresh experience not seen since gen 1 when you had no idea which Pokemon did what. You can't just rely on the same team you've been using for years. This is only a problem for nostalgiafags who want to use their favorite mons only. For people who actually want new experiences it's a positive.

If you hate Game Freak constantly pandering to the KANTOOOO crowd then you better have not been the kind of person who seethed about the Unova-only rule in BW, because then you're apart of the problem.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52985048
>>52988537
The multiple abilities/innates is something with a lot of potential, but I just do not think the way Exceeded implemented it is good.
It's just egregiously awful that so many abilities have additional effects added to them. What the fuck? It's a system built around multiple abilities. If you want multiple effects, you should put them in different abilities to mix and match instead of trying to shove it into a single ability.
I hope the Voyager hack does multiple abilities better. Are there any other hacks implementing multiple abilities?
Anyways, some of my ideas for multiple ability systems:
>separate abilities into innate and learned
>innate abilities can't be changed, reinforcing the pokemon species' identity and playstyle
>learned abilities are either earned through level up from a specific pool in a manner similar to moves, or through special conditions in a manner similar to special evolutions
>learned abilities can be passed down through breeding, allowing for new synergies with abilities not normally learned
>don't allow for a free for all ability fest, as it weakens the reinforcement of a pokemon species' identity and playstyle, as well as enable lazy and broken combos.

>>52988950
>>52991405
>>52991401
If Tyranitar can have any 3 abilities from a pool of 10 that just makes guessing which ability combo your foe's using exponentially harder unless there is literally only one good option.

I love this Innate system. Unironically the best shit I've seen in any hack in decades. Though I do wish RNG was removed from the Innates. Also can "When this Pokemon makes contact with the enemy" and "When the enemy makes contact with this Pokemon" abilities trigger from either type of Contact? A Goodra hitting a foe should apply the Gooey speed loss just like when Goodra is being hit by a foe.

Reminds me of how Effect Monsters worked in Yugioh, back when you had to choose between a strong Normal Monster without an effect (in this case, a strong pokemon with a relatively boring ability/innate set) and an Effect Monster whose effect makes up for his lack of direct power (innates designed to make the pokemon interesting, maybe even strong). And because these Innates are designed for the Pokemon, things actually feel somewhat balanced. Sure, some effects used RNG like Barrel Dragon but that was rare.

I have never actually used a Rattata on my team before. Except when I was 9 and I'd catch shitmons to use as decoys sent out to die when item-healing my Vaporeon and Charizard and Kadabra. But this game makes me want to experiment with gimmicky underpowered shitmons that could finally help my team or serve a useful niche besides "Well SOMEBODY needs to use HMs" or "Guess somebody has to be my Flying type until I can catch the one I want".

I have no clue if there's a more reliable way but from what I've found, copypasting specific variations of autotiles seemingly requires you to do the manual box selection and copy paste the tiles to wherever you need them. unfortunately bringing them to separate layers will require you to copypaste from something that has said tile on the same layer
but if you're trying to copypaste stuff onto other maps you'll have to do an entire process because for some reason the program clears the clipboard when you move over to different maps
>open a separate project that isn't the one you're currently working with
>paste the selected tiles onto whatever map is open in the second project
>do NOT deselect
>move back to the main project window
>switch maps to whatever you're trying to paste things to
>move back to project #2, making sure whatever you pasted is still selected
>copy
>move back to main project
>paste

rmxp is otherwise decently intuitive so I have no clue how they shat the bed so hard in this specific aspect

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53020121
I tackled this issue, at least with regards to bugs, by moving then to midgame and buffing their stats. Since our games are hacks, it is important to be honest with yourself that anyone playing them has already played a lot of pokemon games, and therefore you'll want to shake things up some. The first warning sign of a hack, for me, is if the first 3 routes contain ALL early route mons (bugs, regional normal types regional bird) crammed into the same space in an 8+ pokemon encounter table
Dreadful.
Become comfortable with shifting Pokemon from places you're used to them being, and be prepared to adjust their stats a little accordingly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53022834
>You're desperately trying to find holes
This is the umpteenth time you've responded to criticism with "YOU'RE JUST TRYING TO DISPROVE MY APPROACH!"
Anon, that's what discussion is - identifying talking points about a system you have proposed. The fact that the points are overwhelmingly criticism should prompt you to reflect on why those criticisms are being made, and addressing them in your response or through revision of your game mechanics. Nobody is "trying to find" holes - they are pointing out flaws that are immediately obvious.
Also
>Bug types are fixed by throwing resistances on them
Hardly. A large share of the issue is that bug types are inherently kneecapped, due to their tendency towards early game distribution and rapid evolution. For balance purposes, these things can't have 500 BST immediately available at level 10, when everything else is hovering around 400. This is half-addressed by adding a few single-stage strong bugs in the mid-late game, but doesn't address that others remain utterly useless (for example, Wormadam is a pain to try to use at any point in platinum due to how weak it is)
Redistributing bugs and rewarding them with better BSTs allows them to keep their identity of "raised quickly" while not needing to sacrifice their ability to stand up in the late game.

>>53028092
Because there's a difference between enjoying something and being a "fan" of something. Fandoms are like a brotherhood pact. You're swearing allegiance to something. When it struggles, you struggle. When people oppose it you oppose them. It's blind loyalty caused by a desire to be in a community with others who share the same interests as you.

Companies exploit humanities tendency to want to be in groups by encouraging the concept of the fandom. After all, an extremely loyal group of people willing to support and defend your products is the main goal of every company because it ensures constant revenue.

Don't be a fan, enjoy things.

I like Klara because I like the idea of a bitchy character with a strong sense of self learning to be a better person. She's conceptually fun to begin with and actually has a character arc that she's working on. She has a little bit of lore that isn't super-prominent, but still tells you about where she's coming from.

Contrast this with Iono, who is less complicated, but is very fun in all of her interactions. They're both good, but in different ways, and I actually enjoy both of them quite a lot.

I want to hear Klara's music though. I'm curious about her failed early career.

>What is it?
https://www.pokeclicker.com/
Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?
https://crobat4.github.io/pokeclicker/
A modified version of Pokeclicker that features QoL changes from the original, including a Dock shortcut, type-based pokeball selection, Gen 3+ berries being available in dungeons, un-nerfed experience gains, and some egg-exclusive pokemon being available through other means.

>>53024835
you might think your sarcasm is working as some kind of "gotcha", but you're mistaken. there are indeed different positions for different sections of the game, but each position does not exist in a vacuum with every single person specializing solely in that position. a programmer is assigned to programming roles, modelers are going to be assigned to modeling roles, so-on and so-forth.
if you increase the workload in one section by a significant margin, in this case the actual pokemon development, it requires reallocating more developers to work in that section. more animators have to be assigned to put in the extra work to accommodate whatever new animations are required, more 3D modelers have to to be moved over to updating the preexisting models and textures on top of whatever new pokemon are being added, and various programmers are going to have to make sure the various gameplay systems actually work properly with the newly implemented pokemon without any unintended bugs arising.

implementing 1000+ pokemon every single game, especially to function with the various engine changes and rebalancing is going to either require a major increase in development time (which we all know TPC is never going to do), a major increase in the actual workforce (which TPC is going to continue putting off as long as they are able to) or result in cut corners elsewhere in the game.
the reason sword and shield rightfully got as much shit as it did was because the dex cut showed absolutely no sign of improving the game anywhere else, despite what the actual shills attempted to claim. PLA and SV, however, demonstrated actual improvement in the animation and gameplay department, which was previously absent.

anyways, cope

>>53019210
Depends on what you want out of it.

It IS a competitive fighting game, despite the superficially arena fighter-esque elements: The game still has unique movelists per characters, cancels, just-frames, an attack height system, etc, and the replay value still comes from playing against other people and improving rather then having a ton of modes or single player content. It is much more Street Fighter and less Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm/DBZ budokai.

That said, for a competitive fighting game, it's approachable: There's no motion inputs, everything is either a button, a button plus a direction, two buttons, or holding and releasing a button, so at a low/starting level it's easier to pick up. The way the game handles attack heights and the whole 2d-3d shift mechanic also gives players more breathing room: The phase shift mechanic means you'll never be stuck in the corner the entire match because shifts will break you out of the 2d phase and back into the 3d phase where you're on more neutral ground, and heights exist not as a way to bypass and punish blocking, but to bypass and punish other moves during their active frames, meaning as a newbie you're not worrying about blocking high or low, rather height is a tool for YOU to use when you're on the defensive to get a reversal and hit through one of your enemy's moves.

Note this does not mean that there's less depth at a higher level of play: Some combos, tech, etc top players will be using take a lot of precise timing and dexterity (Garchomp's charge input run stance cancels are as such a lot of chomp players have to change their button layout) , and the whole phase shift mechanic is actually a huge source of an adapational and resource mangement skillgap at top play where players intentionally alter their combo composition and move choices on the fly to cause or delay shifts based on what's to their advantage; and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53019273
>>53019210
cont:

> and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

For example, if you have a move that bypasses and punishes move of X height, and the other player knows you have that, then they can try to use a different combo starter or meaty/on wakeup move or combo ender to try to punish you trying to punish that height

Basically, while it's said so often it's a cliche, Pokken really is "Easy to learn, hard to master": The changes Pokken makes to the fighting game template targets the sort of stuff new players tend to struggle with (motion inputs, being kept in the corner, dealing with what height to block), but those changes don't actually erase the skillgap at high level play and actually add more depth when it comes to neutral (when both players are trying to get a hit in and outwit the other player), having to adapt rather then flowchart, etc: The fact shifts break you back to a neutral state and the height system enables reversals really means there's a lot more back-and-forth where both players are in the driver's seat of the match.

But like any fighting game, you'll get out what you put in: The fun comes from learning, improving, and playing matches, not from unlocks or modes.

>>53019284
Firstly, I think worrying about "is X a good character to start with" is sort of a bad approach to getting into a fighting game: If there's a character or a game you like, start playing. If you worry about getting all the resources (not that frame data, combo guides, common punishes, etc aren't good to know) or starting with an easy character, you can easily pysche yourself out and put off just playing and learning the game/character you actually wanna play.

That being said, he actually is I think one of the easiest characters to start with. He has relatively short combos and just needs like a few stray grabs or short combos or single hits to do big damage. The drawback is he can struggle to get in to land those hits.

>>53019485
The phase shift system is entirely predictable/under the player's control, the tutorial just doesn't explain it.

3d > 2d shifts happen on basically any heavy hit or with most specials. Some lights cause it too. Basically, anything other then light projectiles will shift from 3d to 2d. This is why the game is more a 2d fighter then a 3d one: The 3d phase is basically just an additional buffer layer of neutral play.

2d > 3d shifts occur when the PSP guage is filled, and different moves, on hit, will add more or less points to that guage. Combos that hit 21 hits long also always auto-shift (as an anti-infinite mechanic), as does the universal grab (but not command grabs). However, the guage isn't in the UI, it's something you have to learn and memorize if you wanna keep track of it.

At high level play, players will alter their combos as the match goes on to always end on shifts to do optimum damage vs the shift interrupting the combo. Or they may intentionally go for combos or moves that maybe do less damage or aren't as safe, but that add less PSP, so shifts DON'T happen (thereby keeping the other player in the corner and under pressure, and maybe to get the chance to land an additional combo for more damage in that phase in the long term) or for combos that maybe don't do as much damage but do EXTRA PSP to shift faster, in case they wanna get out of pressure themselves or get the meter/health regen causing a shift gives you. Some moves also reduce or reset the PSP guage.

But like when you're starting out, I wouldn't worry about it that much: Just remember universal grabs always auto shift, heavy hits in the 3d phase shift to 2d, and the more hits you land in 2d the faster you shift to 3d. As it applies to machamp, you should also remember your command grabs do NOT add PSP, so you can use then in the 2d phase as much as you want, and wake up slap REDUCES the guage, allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

Just in case it's not obvious, the reason you want this is because Machamp is a lot better in the 2d phasr then the 3d phase.

Machamp is slow, and is his 3d phase projectiles suck. It's very difficult for machamp to win the field phase and cause the 3d > 2d shift, and he can't do much damage while in the 3d phase.

But even stray hits or single grabs in the 2d phase by machamp do insane damage. It's still hard to actually approach the enemy though, so once machamp IS up close in the 2d phase or especially when you've got the other character in the corner, it's in your interest to keep them there and to continue to land command grabs and rack damage up without causing a shift, most of the time, because it's hard to get back to that position.

In practice, tho, there are obviously situations where you may wanna giove up your advantagious position to land a combo rather then a command grab even if it shifts and allows the enemy to escape: Maybe you aren't comfortable yourself at the moment and just wanna take the damage you can get, maybe you'd really benefit from the extra meter causing a shift brings, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>>53019685
Also also, to be clear, the PSP guage works indepedently for both players.

If you land like 4 hits and almost max out the PSP guage, the enemy landing a hit won't shift: each person has their own guage.

And again, there is no actual visible guage you can look at, sadly: You either need to remember the PSP value of each move, or just reemerge "if I use X move Y times, it will shift" or "If I use Z combo and then land Y move, that will be enough to shift" etc

>Point 2: Comfort Food(s)

In the official Diamond and Pearl series of the Pokémon Anime, Cynthia would often be seen having an ice cream. If this was a one-off joke, then I wouldn't be bringing it up, but she has the stuff a lot in the anime. This can easily be brought up as a possible addiction to some, but for me, it's more of a comfort food. To her, it's familiar, she knows what she's getting every time, and it gives her a soothing sense of familiarity in an ever changing world, which would affect a neurodivergent mind more than a neurotypical one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53009642
Sadly it was doomed to being a shitmon. Rock is just too inaccurate offensively. Stone Edge only has 100 base power despite its atrocious accuracy. Rock Slide is more reliable, but not really worth it. Bombirdier is unironically better off using Brave Bird/Knock Off/Roost/Parting Shot instead of its signature ability. That's way more consistent and Dark/Flying is already decent, with its biggest drawback being that it has a hard time hitting certain Steel types (Steel/Fairy, Steel/Dark, and the less common Steel/Fighting). Rock doesn't help at all with that.

It's kinda like how Aurorus was destined to be a shitmon since there was no way a Sauropod Pokemon was ever going to be fast, and Ice/Rock is atrocious defensively. Bombirdier was designed to be a shitmon from the outset.

Used to be that Smogon didn't care about RNG-based strategies unless they were JUST reliable enough that they basically bypassed the game itself.
Evasion boosts were the prime offenders but things like Brightpowder were seen as irrelevant because they'd only affect a match once in a blue moon.
The current Smogon community's line of thinking is that any and all factors that so much as encourage an RNG-based strategy, no matter how fallible and innocuous, are inherently uncompetitive and must be removed.

Not a lot of setup opportunities because the glues of the tier can all hit it for good damage or cripple it besides Ting-Lu or Rotom, meanwhile more defensive teams have their Unaware walls that can halt its sweep like a Tera'd Skeledirge or Dondozo. Speed Tiers in offensive tiers are also a little fucked with the likes of Valiant with Energy Booster among counterplay for it so even at +1 against offense you're still not winning necessarily. It also faces competition with Dragonite as a wincon and I think Tera Normal Dragonite has a lot going for it, Roaring Moon as well.
Not a bad Pokémon though, a sleeper pick.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53028189
it's an interesting thing.
they design "just gets bigger" pokemon because they start by designing the first stage and then put every design element they want in the whole line into the first stage already. they like their design so they don't expand upon it much or change its elements at all. if they come up with something that could work into an evolution that would actually be different, they just think "no need to change it when it evolves, I'll just make this into a new pokemon" which is why fakemon dex's have overlapping ideas in several of their designs sometimes.
then there's the fact that fakemon artists RARELY get this constructive criticism. the criticism fakemon artists get, 90% of the time, is "this looks like [existing pokemon] or [existing fakemon]" which might make them tweak their design but it won't make them stop it from just getting bigger when it evolves.

>>53025763
Spidop's best niche, near as I can tell, is that it has access to three different entry hazards. I think the best way to improve it, in that case, is to make it better at using them.

Operantula (Operator+Tarantula)
Bug/Dark
Mold Breaker(Stakeout)
91 HP
100 ATK
119 DEF
65 SPA
103 SPD
47 SPE
New moves: Knock Off, Fake Out

This gives it some much needed bulk, a new ability lets it guarantee that those hazards go up, and Knock Off and Fake Out give it some nice support tools for doubles. It is still quite slow, so outside of Trick Room it'll usually go last, and it doesn't have any reliable recovery, so it's still prone to getting worn down, but I think it's ultimately a usable evolution for a neat pokemon.

>>53005956
Gen 2 overall does a good job in having variety, though I think the fact that so much of that variety is Gen 1 mons is why it rubs people the wrong way.
It also doesn't help when a lot of the rare Gen 2 mons that are locked to postgame or are rare or hard to find aren't even that great.

Like you can go out of your way for mons like Yanma, Aipom, or Sunflora, but they're not exactly great team members. Even certain postgame mons wouldn't be anything too crazy if they were available earlier, with how Misdreavus is largely on par with Haunter, and Magcargo is pretty outclassed as a Fire type.
Murkrow would probably be quite useful, though mainly because the other Dark type option is just Umbreon, or Sneasel in Crystal.
It's one thing to want to make the new pokemon rare so that they're more special, and in some cases like Tyranitar I think it works very well, but very few Gen 2 mons feel like they're powerful enough to really warrant how elusive they are.

not reading that because i can tell it's not about the image I was replying to.
gen 5 fixed HMs before cutting them because the only mandatory ones were strength and surf (cut at the start but they give you a pokemon with it right next to the tree and then you never have to use it again) and the strength boulders are set in place so you don't have to keep a pokemon with it just to go places you've already been (and most of those places are optional anyway) you literally never need an HM slave in BW. this was a direct response to HMs being the worst they've ever been in gen 4.
it fixed the new pokemon distribution problem by having all new pokemon with the best distribution yet, and there's never an abundance of pokemon you've seen before in any area.
AND it fixed the problem of dungeons just being linear "use HM a couple times" nothingcaves by making stuff like chargestone cave with the pushing magnetised crystals gimmick, relic castle with the quicksand gimmick and even just stuff like dragonspiral tower having the circling camera so you can map out the correct path is cooler than anything sinnoh did. they're also more visually appealing with stuff like walking through logs in pinwheel forest and walking on planks you have to balance on and can fall off of in some areas while diamond and pearl had defog, need I remind you)

Its effect really depends onhow much you think about your team. If you value the actual training and battling, it's very noticable when there aren't many thing to catch early on, because that is when you are levelling the fastest and changing your team often, so you want to see all of your options. If you just catch random thigns as you go, you may grab the first few rat/bird/whatever pokemon you see and not pay attention to wild mons after that.
It also effects replays more, if you don't want repeat mons, you can only go through johto maybe 2 or 3 times (depending on past experience with Kantomons) before there is nothing easily available you haven't already used.

It's absolutely an argument based in post-hoc logic. It all boils down to people wishing they could use a certain Pokemon earlier than when it's normally available. The concept of certain Pokemon not showing up until later in the game ends up having very little impact on the game itself, especially if you're playing it for the first time and have no context of what is or isn't available at any given time. No one found a Houndour for the first time in Gold/Silver and said
>FUCK, WHY COULDN'T I FIND THIS TEN HOURS AGO?
What they actually said was
>HOLY SHIT, A HOUNDOUR!
Which is the entire point. The game is designed so that you're finding new shit, all the way to the last area of the game. But teambuilding autists who want a Houndoom or Tyranitar on their team can't help but seethe because their dream team won't be complete until they're 99% done with the game. hardly a perfect implementation, but it serves its purpose, and anyone who screeches about it has either missed the point or is ignoring the point.

The problem comes in that most players are going to want to fill out their teams fairly early.
Especially in regions were there is a necessity to use multiple HMs.
So having too many backloaded monsters means that a lot of them won't appear to the player until very late in the game. Sometimes too late for players to want to make them a part of their team.

Ideally most of your interesting monsters will have appeared before the 4-5th gym.
As most past that point will have to replace members of the player's team. In a game series that disincentivizes doing that by talking up the bonds between player and monster.

>>53023227
The idea in the first few gens is that the story and the pokemon battles should be made easier and linear for casual players, and that the real challenge of the game is finding and catching all the pokemon - so what really mattered was coming up with different ways to find pokemon, and that line of thought peaked with gsc legendaries' (which require a very optimal strategy and patience to capture legitimately).

The first indication that this begun to change was with crystal - the add battle tower there is clearly meant to allow hardcore players to test their teambuilding abilities against a a big number of competent AI teams.

This shows in the way gen 3 mons were balanced against each other, but i would say that it only became the main focus from generation 4 and onward.

>>53000951
You have to analize it from both sides

>Grim Darkwood
He is edge incarnated, his team can set up field effects, and many of their moves are game breakers, but looks like his main carrier is Tyranitar, so the rest is just fodder (so to speak).
Now, let's analyze Tyranitar: 31 IVs, 252 in all stats. But this is only in his first form. If Grim enters Berserk state, I imagine this can give him like a 100 BST bonus to Tyranitar, in his second form. Now the third one is the "funny one", since is Grim fused with his pokemon. This probably gives it a 200/300 BST boost, and the 3 only weakness rule is good, but it also makes him a glass cannon. If you have a team that has good move coverage, his final form can crumble just as easy. A Focus Sash - Endeavor - Quick Attack Rattata does the job because his tactic is "All in, all out". Grim's weakness is his own hubris, so you must hit there.

>Vox Xavion
Team is Smogon incarnated, probably they are 31 IVs, 252 EVs thanks to Dorado's drugs. But this isn't a bad thing per se.
While Grim shines in carrying on with his edge, Xavion is more of a tactician, and this makes his team more "situational". Let's not forget he also manipulated his team's DNA to make them "human". I imagine Landorus is more agile, and Lucario has a better fighting style. But speaking of Lucario, she is probably the weakest one. All Xavion does is use her as her spooge rag when miss schizo is busy/"controlling herself", so maybe her stats are weaker.
Defeat Lucario, and you have an opening. The second (and probably most dangerous) problem is Lustrorious. His typing is Fairy/Poison (if I remember correctly), but this typing changes in his second AND third form. And Xavion can fise with it, so I imagine it also has a BST boost. Lustrorious probably will have a powerful BST, considering it's a legendary (or a pseudo), so the fight will be a hard one.

It all depends in which situation we are: game logic or anime logic.

posts.name: Anonymous.
posts.com:
>>52994615
>Apparently weakness advantage
Doesn't matter if your team is strong and fast enough
>all my old sync pairs are worthless now since team building is now based on themes or something.
Team Building is based on buffing your most powerful DPS as fast as possible. This includes crits, terrains, zones. and weather, as well as debuffing your opponents' defenses including type rebuffs. Most units are "worthless" if compared to the most broken units that are out in the game, but since the majority of stages can be beaten without broken units barring certain EBs and the highest LG win streaks, "old" sync pairs can stull find their place from time to time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52994615
A weather/terrain/wish seems to be the latest meta trend that everyone does, but for starter, a buffs/debuffs are more important to stay your team alive so have sync pairs that can at least raise stats and crits. Also check Area Details for opponents because DeNa always plays own rules especially Extreme Battle Event.

>>53002577
Which type do you have less good pairs for, Rock or Ghost? That should really be helpful in deciding which one to get, as it's hard to say for sure without context. I'd probably advise for Korrina, since SS Diantha could cover your Rock needs.

Emmet can be a devastating Rock striker considering he maxes all his offensive stats by himself and has both single target and AOE moves. He does require sandstorm setup to max out his effectiveness though so you'll need setters like his bro, Anni or Lodge Raihan, or Bertha, hell Acerola would probably do. Also consider that both of his moves have below-average accuracy, and considering he's gauge heavy missing can hurt. He does gain Piercing Gaze with his grid but only at 3/5.

SS Korrina buffs all allies' crits and buffs herself quite nicely too, making her great for double DPS. Her ability to steal stats three times is highly valuable against buff-reliant opponents, especially since it helps her get her sync multiplier. She can hit deceptively hard even with her 2 gauge moves, since Spectral Thief activates damage multipliers for two of her passives at once. Most importantly she has exposed tummy She's not a necessity if you have good ghost pairs like Anni Lillie or SSR Cynthia, but it definitely doesn't hurt to have her.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

>>53023867
These don't make much sense when looking at a broader picture. Basically the eeveelutions throw a wrench at this viewpoint as well as Pokémon that maintain consistency in general polls. For example Smash or Pass polls show the eeveelutions like Glaceon, Vaporeon and Sylveon outperforming the likes of Pokémon like Hatterene, Meloetta and Tsareena in almost every category. It shows that even in more general polls these Pokémon maintain a higher position, the whole "more human looking = popularity" doesn't materialize in our data, very much so the opposite happens at times. Simply put Pokémon aren't human-adjacent enough creatures for that to actually matter. Vaporeon existing in the popular imagination when it comes to Pokémon sexualization also says plenty.

If we look at a even broader picture outside of polls it also manifests in general imageboards, and surprisingly even in anime orientated imageboards.

Example of the highest rated Pokémon picture in imageboards where the human characters dominate:
Paheal: Pikachu Libre
Rule34.xxx: Umbreon
Gelbooru: Lopunny
Reddit r/rule34: Vaporeon
Twitter: Meowscarada

More interesting is that Pokémon start clumping together in these imageboard too. Here's an example of Vaporeon outscoring Gardevoir where Pokegirls dominate. The human looking aspect is severely overplayed when it comes to talking about NSFW. Most people don't view, and the series doesn't either, Pokémon as human adjacent enough for it to actually matter. Pokémon attraction tends to be pretty close with Gardevoir being the front face of feminine designs, but not dominating over the others, and Lucario being the front face of masculine designs.

It's a character design thing. A Zoroark's ponytail, particularly the part after the bead, is in the same place you'd find a fox tail if it was attached to their keester. So they gave it a real, if rather stubby stand in.

I'd say Hoenn > Kanto = Unova BW2 > Johto > Unova BW >> Sinnoh.
I really dislike slow starts, which is why Hoenn is up there. Getting a good choice early is very important I think.
Kanto does a really "jack-of-all-trades" job, there's no real massive flaw aside from too much VEs. It just works.
BW Unova just has really good type balance, but yes the start is abysmal and the region generally suffers from the "all new mons" autism.
BW2 Unova is fucking weird lol. the availability stays strong all along with early Sewaddle, Magby, Mareep, Psyduck etc, then Route 4, then Reversal Mountain. But it just feels really shitty to have Munna and Cubchoo in postgame-only
I used to really like the whole "you have to work for the mons" thing in Johto, until I realized it ended making my playthroughs pretty sluggish, as mid-game I tend to finally get the mons I want (Xatu, Lanturn, Sneasel etc) but need to grind them, for no real reason because those mons aren't exactly even good.
Sinnoh... What even is there to say here? First four routes have like four mons in total. bruh. Too many gimmick ways to get mons, especially Honey is AIDS. New evos locked to postgame sucks, but that would be fairly okay if Sinnoh actually had enough mons to choose from. The variety of new mons is just even worse than Kalos, shit making no sense.

posts.com: I'm excited and nervous about starting Emerald after finishing Crystal. Do you guys particularly concerned with Natures/Abilities/EVs or do you just roll with the punches?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53027277
Depends on the encounter and game state, some pokemon become liabilities with a bad nature, IVs, and movepool; like -SpA Ralts with poor SpA IVs. While fine as a Gardevoir later on due to the huge Base Stat it won't be strong enough to get there as a normal party member considering it's after the fourth badge. Then at the point where you could level it up to use it, you'll have access to other pokemon, hopefully ones with better stat distributions.

Some notable ones with the issue are
>Treecko
The worst starter in terms of early-mid game
>Poochyena
Without a decent Atk/SpA, won't do enough damage until you it before Wattson. Has Howl but is way too frail to use it. Mightyena has some utility however.
>Beautifly
Too weak and limited in moves to handle poor offensive stats
>Lombre and Nuzleaf
They need stats to balance out their awful movepools
>Ralts
As stated above

Then there's the inverse
>Mudkip and Torchic
Decent moves, coverage, and resistances balance out poor stats
>Zigzagoon
Has pick Up and gets early Headbutt which is a STAB 70 power move with a flinch chance, that with Sand-Attack, Tail Whip and Growl gives a way to set up for other pokemon
>Taillow and Wingull
Access to early Wing Attack and Water gun, respectively, are extremely useful and strong.
>Dustox
It doesn't rely on its stats as it's focused on status and support

>too many secrets and full arts
That only matters based on the pull rates, in 36packs in the SwSh era, you'd be lucky to get 1 alt art out of 3 to 4 boxes. And as for full arts they were split across 3 differnt catagories; Pokemon, Trainer, and Rainbow rares. Basically moving into SV will be a success depending on if they up the rare count to packs opened. Assuming anything that was a V or above was considered a hit, you average on 8 hits per box and you weren't always guarenteed a secret, alt, or even hyper rare per box; which is the shits.
If they say upped the boxes to be 12 (at minimum) and at least 1 of those was a full art, alt art and secret rare, then I'd say the sets would be fine. That's a foolish dream tho, but; I do hope the SV series takes a hit in sales with them upping the price and they learn people will only buy from the third market since buying packs is a losing battle more than 75% of the time.
Personally, I don't think I'll be buying packs anymore, or at the very least less than 10 per set and get the rest from online singles. Which is sad, because I like ripping packs, oh well.
